noun.description: The side or part of an object that presents itself to view or that is normally seen or used first; the most forward part of something.
examples: a page at the front of the book had been torn out
he sealed the envelope and wrote on the front

noun.description: The foremost line or part of an armed force; the furthest position that an army has reached and where the enemy is or may be engaged.
examples: his regiment was immediately sent to the front

noun.description: An appearance or form of behavior assumed by a person to conceal their genuine feelings.
examples: she put on a brave front
he's got a bit of talent and a lot of front
the front cover of the magazine
she was in the front yard

adjective.description: (of a vowel sound) formed by raising the tongue, excluding the blade and tip, toward the hard palate.

verb.description: (of a building or piece of land) have the front facing or directed toward.
examples: the houses that front Beacon Street
we sold the uphill land that fronted on the road

verb.description: Provide (something) with a front or facing of a particular type or material.
examples: a metal box fronted by an alloy panel

verb.description: Lead or be the most prominent member in (an organization, activity, or group of musicians)
examples: the group is fronted by two girl singers

verb.description: Act as a front or cover for someone or something acting illegally or wishing to conceal something.
examples: he fronted for them in illegal property deals

verb.description: Stand face to face with; confront.
examples: Tom fronted him with unwavering eyes

verb.description: Articulate (a vowel sound) with the tongue further forward.
examples: all speakers use raised and fronted variants more in spontaneous speech

verb.description: Place (a sentence element) at the beginning of a sentence instead of in its usual position, typically for emphasis or as a feature of some dialects, as in horrible it was.

exclamation.description: Used to summon someone to the front or to command them to assume a forward-facing position, as in calling a bellhop to the front desk or giving orders to troops on parade.

phrases: the car in front stopped suddenly
The tank in front moved forward and engaged the convoy in the open area.
Should a child run out in front, we can stop far quicker than any car.
So it is extremely hard to get close to the car in front, let alone pass it.
On one side fields stretch out into blackness, but in front and to the right blaze thousands of halogen lamps.
origin: Middle English (denoting the forehead): from Old French front (noun), fronter (verb), from Latin frons, front- forehead, front.
